body:
Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "[Fundy](https://www.youtube.com/fundy)" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...*this December*?!

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his [twitter account](https://twitter.com/fundylive). And behold, the video from this December really *was* the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner *and* they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a *beginner*, which didn't sit right with me.

[1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1212051427079667720)

[1 million views on his first few videos in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1216193854816313344)

[50k subs in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1221755156087353345)

[100k in March](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1240043074639876097)

[200k in April](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1255536659707412483)

[270k a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1261283315417518081)

After that it's literally about 100k per week

[400k a month later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1274152818891526147)

[700k 2 weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1277599336784891904)

[1 million a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1284901504281968641)

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch was created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he *did* have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

And just now I found two more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see when I was going to post this on +Minecraft is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

For reference, here's the statistics of his super legitimate growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

And just now I found two more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

GeorgeNotFound

Dream

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see when I was going to post this on +Minecraft is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

post.title: Do you think the new wave of Minecraft YouTubers that suddenly popped up out of nowhere are just industry plants?

body:
Now I’m convinced that they could actually be industry plants. But the stuff they do has to be real. Dream has done at least some legitimate speedruns and create some cool plugins. Fundy has also made some cool stuff in Minecraft. As you said, youtube would do this to whoever they think they could make money on. The skills of those people certainly attract people’s attention. It might not be the most ethical business strategy, but they produce entertaining content if you don’t look too far into it.

Side note: I feel that collaborations with other youtubers would be important for growing popularity. Has the guy with 7.2k subs done any collaborations?

[1 million views on his first few videos in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1216193854816313344)

[50k subs in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1221755156087353345)

[100k in March](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1240043074639876097)

[200k in April](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1255536659707412483)

[270k a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1261283315417518081)

After that it's literally about 100k per week

[400k a month later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1274152818891526147)

[700k 2 weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1277599336784891904)

[1 million a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1284901504281968641)

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch was created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he *did* have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

And just now I found two more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see when I was going to post this on +Minecraft is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

body:
BadBoyHalo is nowhere near as popular as those 3. Plus, that wouldn't explain GeorgeNotFound or the most rapidly growing, Fundy.

It's 100% from YT shoving all their videos in the suggestions imo. No wonder everyone else complains about never being able to get listed there.

It just sucks because I see really solid channels like [this one](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXhOllcCZNLuv4WeXvQasNQ) get < 10k subs in years, with tons of videos, and < 10k views per video. And ones that did get popular after years and years like AntVenom, but still only get like 300k views per video. But then these noobs get a million views on their first video for no reason, then continue getting 1,000,000-5,000,000 views on every single video without even trying, and a massive cult following because their name shows up everywhere.

There are literally videos about fucking supercomputers in Minecraft made out of command blocks, yet Fundy gets 3M views for sending his monitor pixels to a minecraft server. I have no idea how choosing that over the former makes YT more money. He doesn't even use SEO, so it's definitely YT that's making his ranks higher. And now all anyone talks about is his difficulty mods and you can't even go on this tiny site without hearing about it non fucking stop. SO amazing, someone made a mod that makes Minecraft harder, how new and exciting. Revolutionary, never been done before!

Don't get me wrong, I like his channel and think the videos are entertaining, but this is absolute BS.

[50k subs in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1221755156087353345)

[100k in March](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1240043074639876097)

[200k in April](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1255536659707412483)

[270k a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1261283315417518081)

After that it's literally about 100k per week

[400k a month later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1274152818891526147)

[700k 2 weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1277599336784891904)

[1 million a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1284901504281968641)

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch was created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he *did* have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

And just now I found two more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see when I was going to post this on +Minecraft is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)
post.body_html:
Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "Fundy" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...this December?!

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his twitter account. And behold, the video from this December really was the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner and they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a beginner, which didn't sit right with me.

1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day

1 million views on his first few videos in January

50k subs in January

100k in March

200k in April

270k a few weeks later

After that it's literally about 100k per week

400k a month later

700k 2 weeks later

1 million a few weeks later

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch was created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he did have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

Proof of older videos that were removed

For reference, here's the statistics of his super legitimate growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

And just now I found two more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

GeorgeNotFound

Dream

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the "living in a van" channel.

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see when I was going to post this on +Minecraft is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

body:
Fundy mostly did average gaming videos before, then they all suddenly disappeared and he instantly got insanely high quality editing and lots of crazy ideas, which just so happened to get millions of views and get recommended to everyone even when he didn't have hardly any subscribers yet. They were of a different sort than his previous ones, which were mostly hobby gaming and not actual YouTubing, nothing special really. I think they did have collaborations but mostly with each other, and it was after they already got tons of views out of nowhere. You can't really do that when you're a nobody, so no the 7.2k guy didn't have any collabs that I'm aware of.

It's on YT for sure. Most of their ideas have been done before, but never got that much attention. And I can pull up an entirely unrelated video and there will still be at least 3 Fundy videos in the suggestions feed, as well as Dream. Just to clarify, this is *after* clearing all watch and search history.

parent.body:
Now I’m convinced that they could actually be industry plants. But the stuff they do has to be real. Dream has done at least some legitimate speedruns and create some cool plugins. Side note: I feel that collaborations with other youtubers would be important for growing popularity. Has the guy with 7.2k subs done any collaborations?

But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...*this December*?!

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his [twitter account](https://twitter.com/fundylive). And behold, the video from this December really *was* the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner *and* they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a *beginner*, which didn't sit right with me.

[1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1212051427079667720)

[1 million views on his first few videos in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1216193854816313344)

[50k subs in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1221755156087353345)

[100k in March](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1240043074639876097)

[200k in April](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1255536659707412483)

[270k a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1261283315417518081)

After that it's literally about 100k per week

[400k a month later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1274152818891526147)

[700k 2 weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1277599336784891904)

[1 million a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1284901504281968641)

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch was created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he *did* have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

And just now I found two more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see when I was going to post this on +Minecraft is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

body:
Not sure, I never watched him. I doubt it's 100% legit, but nothing at that scale will be.

It's funny that you bring him up though. Even he took 2 years to hit a million subscribers. I get that the site was smaller back then, but this is *PewDiePie* we're talking about here, plus there was less competition so it may have actually been easier. So a million in 6 months on some Minecraft channels with 30 videos is...yeah, *super* legit.

[400k a month later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1274152818891526147)

[700k 2 weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1277599336784891904)

[1 million a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1284901504281968641)

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch was created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he *did* have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

And just now I found two more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see when I was going to post this on +Minecraft is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)
post.body_html:
Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "Fundy" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...this December?!

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his twitter account. And behold, the video from this December really was the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner and they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a beginner, which didn't sit right with me.

1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day

1 million views on his first few videos in January

50k subs in January

100k in March

200k in April

270k a few weeks later

After that it's literally about 100k per week

400k a month later

700k 2 weeks later

1 million a few weeks later

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch was created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he did have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

Proof of older videos that were removed

For reference, here's the statistics of his super legitimate growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

And just now I found two more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

GeorgeNotFound

Dream

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the "living in a van" channel.

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see when I was going to post this on +Minecraft is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

post.title: Do you think the new wave of Minecraft YouTubers that suddenly popped up out of nowhere are just industry plants?

body: When I say left to chance, I mean that once a methodology for generating revenue is found, they're not just going to sit idly by and ignore it. They want viral content to generate clicks to earn advertising dollars, and they'll manufacture it in as controlled a fashion as they can manage rather than allowing it to develop organically. Handpicking certain individuals is just a small part of content farming, the same way picking movie stars is no longer the focus of Hollywood, blockbuster franchises built around ensembles, effects and safe concepts is. You ever notice how we don't really have any real movie stars anymore, aside from legacy figures holding on to fame as they age? No one that Hollywood has gotten behind in recent times has become the same kind of iconic cultural figure that the stars from decades ago emerged as.

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see when I was going to post this on +Minecraft is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)
post.body_html:
Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "Fundy" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...this December?!

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his twitter account. And behold, the video from this December really was the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner and they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a beginner, which didn't sit right with me.

1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day

1 million views on his first few videos in January

50k subs in January

100k in March

200k in April

270k a few weeks later

After that it's literally about 100k per week

400k a month later

700k 2 weeks later

1 million a few weeks later

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch was created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he did have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

Proof of older videos that were removed

For reference, here's the statistics of his super legitimate growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

And just now I found two more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

GeorgeNotFound

Dream

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the "living in a van" channel.

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see when I was going to post this on +Minecraft is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

parent.body: When I say left to chance, I mean that once a methodology for generating revenue is found, they're not just going to sit idly by and ignore it. They want viral content to generate clicks to earn advertising dollars, and they'll manufacture it in as controlled a fashion as they can manage rather than allowing it to develop organically. Handpicking certain individuals is just a small part of content farming, the same way picking movie stars is no longer the focus of Hollywood, blockbuster franchises built around ensembles, effects and safe concepts is. You ever notice how we don't really have any real movie stars anymore, aside from legacy figures holding on to fame as they age? No one that Hollywood has gotten behind in recent times has become the same kind of iconic cultural figure that the stars from decades ago emerged as.

1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day

1 million views on his first few videos in January

50k subs in January

100k in March

200k in April

270k a few weeks later

After that it's literally about 100k per week

400k a month later

700k 2 weeks later

1 million a few weeks later

GeorgeNotFound

Dream

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the "living in a van" channel.

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.
